title: Troubleshooting Guide
text: Common issues and solutions for SMM635 computing setup.

title: Troubleshooting Guide
text:
Installation Issues

Python/Anaconda






conda: command not found





Problem: Terminal doesn’t recognize conda commands
Solutions: 1. Windows: Add Anaconda to PATH - Search “Environment Variables” in Start Menu - Add C:\Users\YourName\Anaconda3\Scripts to PATH - Restart terminal

Mac/Linux: Source conda
source ~/anaconda3/bin/activate
conda init
Alternative: Use Anaconda Prompt (Windows) or full path










Package conflicts during installation





Problem: “Solving environment” takes forever or fails
Solutions: 1. Create fresh environment: bash    conda create -n smm635_fresh python=3.9    conda activate smm635_fresh    conda install matplotlib seaborn plotly

Use mamba (faster solver):
conda install -n base mamba
mamba install package_name
Use pip for specific packages:
pip install plotly --upgrade






R/RStudio






“Package not available for R version”





Problem: Can’t install certain packages
Solutions: 1. Update R to latest version 2. Install from source: r    install.packages("package_name", type = "source") 3. Use development version: r    devtools::install_github("author/package")









RStudio won’t start





Problem: RStudio crashes or shows blank screen
Solutions: 1. Reset RStudio state: - Mac: rm -rf ~/.rstudio-desktop - Windows: Delete %localappdata%\RStudio-Desktop

Update graphics drivers
Try RStudio Cloud as temporary solution

title: Troubleshooting Guide
text:
Runtime Errors

Python






ModuleNotFoundError





Problem: Python can’t find installed package
Solutions: 1. Check you’re in correct environment: bash    conda activate smm635    conda list  # Should show your packages

Reinstall package:
conda install package_name -c conda-forge
Check Jupyter kernel:
python -m ipykernel install --user --name smm635










Matplotlib figures not showing





Problem: Plots don’t appear in notebook
Solutions: 1. Add magic command: python    %matplotlib inline

For interactive plots:
%matplotlib widget
Explicitly show plots:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
plt.show()






R






“could not find function”





Problem: R doesn’t recognize function
Solutions: 1. Load the library: r    library(ggplot2)  # or appropriate package

Use full namespace:
ggplot2::ggplot(...)
Check spelling and case sensitivity










ggplot shows blank plot





Problem: No output from ggplot
Solutions: 1. Assign and print: r    p <- ggplot(data, aes(x, y)) + geom_point()    print(p)

Check data isn’t empty:
nrow(data)  # Should be > 0

title: Troubleshooting Guide
text:
Performance Issues






Slow plotting with large datasets





Solutions: 1. Sample data: python    df_sample = df.sample(n=10000)

Use datashader for millions of points:
import datashader as ds
Aggregate before plotting:
df_summary <- df %>%
  group_by(category) %>%
  summarize(mean_value = mean(value))










Jupyter notebook keeps crashing





Solutions: 1. Increase memory limit: python    import resource    resource.setrlimit(resource.RLIMIT_AS, (2147483648, 2147483648))

Clear output regularly:

Cell → All Output → Clear

Use .py scripts for heavy processing

title: Troubleshooting Guide
text:
Git/GitHub Issues






Permission denied (publickey)





Problem: Can’t push to GitHub
Solutions: 1. Use HTTPS instead of SSH: bash    git remote set-url origin https://github.com/user/repo.git

Set up SSH key:
ssh-keygen -t ed25519
cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub
# Copy and add to GitHub settings
Use GitHub Desktop or VS Code git integration










Large files rejected





Problem: GitHub won’t accept files > 100MB
Solutions: 1. Use .gitignore: *.csv    data/    *.pkl

Use Git LFS:
git lfs track "*.csv"
git add .gitattributes
Store data externally (Google Drive, Dropbox)

title: Welcome to SMM635!

Welcome to the course website for SMM635 - Data Visualization
This module will teach you how to create effective and beautiful data visualizations using modern tools and techniques. You’ll learn both the theory behind good visualization design and practical skills in Python and R.

title: Welcome to SMM635!
text:
Course overview
Data visualization is the art and science of transforming data into visual representations that effectively communicate insights, patterns, and stories. In this module, you will:

Learn fundamental principles of visual perception and design
Master data visualization tools including matplotlib, seaborn, ggplot2, and plotly
Create static and interactive visualizations
Develop skills in exploratory data analysis
Build compelling data stories and dashboards
Work with different data types: temporal, spatial, network, and text data

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text:
Technical Questions

What computer specifications do I need?

Minimum: 8GB RAM, 256GB storage, any OS
Recommended: 16GB RAM, 512GB storage, dedicated graphics card
Lab computers are available if your laptop doesn’t meet requirements



Can I use my tablet/iPad?
Tablets are great for reading and sketching, but you’ll need a laptop or desktop for coding assignments. Cloud-based options like Google Colab can work in a pinch.


Which IDE should I use?
We recommend: - Python: VS Code or JupyterLab - R: RStudio - Both: VS Code with appropriate extensions
Choose what you’re comfortable with!


Do I need to install everything before the first class?
No, we’ll have an installation party during the first lab. However, attempting installation beforehand helps identify issues early.

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text:
Assignment Questions

Can I submit assignments late?
Late submissions incur a 10% penalty per day. After 5 days, assignments won’t be accepted. See syllabus for emergency extension policy.


How are group projects graded?
Group projects receive a base grade, with individual adjustments based on: - Peer evaluations - Individual contribution statements - Git commit history


Can I use code from the internet?
Yes, with proper attribution! You must: - Cite all sources - Understand any code you use - Adapt it to your specific needs - Never copy entire solutions


What constitutes plagiarism in visualization?

Copying code without attribution
Reproducing others’ visualizations without credit
Submitting others’ work as your own
Using generative AI without disclosure

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text:
Project Questions

Can I use my work/research data for projects?
Absolutely! Real-world data makes projects more meaningful. Ensure: - You have permission to use the data - No confidential information is included - Data is appropriately anonymized - You can share it with classmates for peer review


What makes a good final project?
Strong final projects typically: - Tell a compelling data story - Use appropriate visualization techniques - Include interactive elements - Show technical proficiency - Demonstrate design principles - Are well-documented


Can I continue working on my project after the course?
Yes! Many students develop their projects into: - Portfolio pieces - Research publications - Open-source contributions - Startup ideas

Complete all course projects thoughtfully

Create personal projects with interesting data
Document your process, not just results

title: Frequently Asked Questions

Practical Matters

Is lecture attendance mandatory?
Lectures aren’t mandatory but strongly encouraged. We don’t record lectures to encourage participation and discussion. Slides are posted after class.


Can I audit the course?
Contact the instructor to discuss auditing options. Auditors are welcome in lectures but may have limited access to labs and computing resources.


Are there prerequisites I should review?
Review these topics before the course: - Basic statistics (mean, median, distributions) - Data manipulation (filtering, grouping, joining) - File I/O in your chosen language


How do I get help if I’m struggling?

Attend office hours early and often
Form study groups
Post on the course forum
Visit TA hours
Reach out to the instructor

Don’t wait until you’re behind!







Didn’t find your question?



Post it on the course forum or ask during office hours. We’ll add common questions to this FAQ throughout the term.


Remember: There are no stupid questions! If you’re wondering about something, others probably are too.

Required Software

1. Python Environment
We recommend using Anaconda, which includes Python and essential data science packages.

Installation Steps

Download Anaconda

Visit anaconda.com/download
Choose Python 3.9+ version for your operating system
Download the installer (graphical installer recommended)

Install Anaconda

Run the installer
Accept default settings
Important: Add Anaconda to your PATH (Windows users)

# Download the environment file from course repo
curl -O https://raw.githubusercontent.com/simoneSantoni/data-viz-smm635/main/resources/smm635.yaml

conda env create -f smm635.yaml

python --version  # Should show Python 3.9+

title: Syllabus
text: SMM635 Data Visualization is a comprehensive introduction to the principles and practice of data visualization. This module combines theoretical foundations with hands-on experience using industry-standard tools and programming languages. Students will learn to create effective, ethical, and aesthetically pleasing visualizations that communicate complex data insights to diverse audiences.

title: Syllabus
text:
Learning Outcomes
Upon successful completion of this module, students will be able to:

Analyze the effectiveness of data visualizations using principles of visual perception and design
Design appropriate visualizations for different data types and communication objectives
Implement static and interactive visualizations using Python, R, and web technologies
Evaluate the ethical implications of design choices in data visualization
Create comprehensive data stories that effectively communicate insights

title: Syllabus

Lectures (2 hours/week): Theory, principles, and case studies
Labs (2 hours/week): Hands-on coding and visualization practice
Self-study (6 hours/week): Readings, tutorials, and assignments

title: Project Tips & Resources
text:
What makes a good dataset for visualization? - Multiple variables (quantitative and categorical) - Temporal or spatial components - Sufficient observations for meaningful patterns - Clean enough to use, messy enough to be interesting - Tells a story you care about
Where to find datasets: - See our data sources list - Your own research or work (with permission) - APIs from services you use - Web scraping (check robots.txt) - Government open data portals



Always start with exploratory data analysis:
# Quick data overview
import pandas as pd
df = pd.read_csv('your_data.csv')
print(df.info())
print(df.describe())
print(df.head())

# Check for missing values
print(df.isnull().sum())

# Quick visualizations
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
df.hist(figsize=(12, 8))
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()









Paper First!



Sketch at least 5 different visualization approaches on paper before coding. This helps you: - Think through the story - Identify required data transformations
- Plan interactive elements - Save time overall

title: Project Tips & Resources
text:
Design Best Practices

Color Selection

Start with grayscale - Ensure it works without color
Use color purposefully - Highlight, group, or encode
Check accessibility - Use colorblind-safe palettes
Be consistent - Same color = same meaning



Typography

Hierarchy: Use size and weight to guide the eye
Readability: Sans-serif for screens, adequate size
Consistency: Maximum 2 font families
Labels: Direct labeling > legends when possible



Layout Principles

Visual hierarchy: Most important elements prominent
White space: Let visualizations breathe
Alignment: Create clean sight lines
Balance: Distribute visual weight evenly

title: Project Tips & Resources
text:
Technical Tips

Performance Optimization
For large datasets:
# Sampling for development
df_dev = df.sample(n=10000, random_state=42)

# Aggregation before plotting
df_agg = df.groupby('category').agg({
    'value': ['mean', 'std', 'count']
}).reset_index()

# Use efficient libraries
import datashader as ds  # For millions of points
import vaex  # For out-of-core computation


Interactive Features
Start simple, add complexity: 1. Hover tooltips - Show details on demand 2. Filtering - Let users focus on subsets 3. Zooming/panning - Explore dense regions 4. Linked views - Coordinate multiple charts 5. Animations - Show change over time


Deployment Options
For sharing your work: - Static: GitHub Pages, Netlify - Python apps: Streamlit, Dash, Heroku - R apps: Shiny, shinyapps.io - Notebooks: Binder, Google Colab - Dashboards: Tableau Public, Observable

title: Project Tips & Resources
text:
Project Management

Version Control
# Initialize git repository
git init
git add .
git commit -m "Initial project setup"

# Create .gitignore
echo "data/large_file.csv" >> .gitignore
echo "*.pyc" >> .gitignore
echo ".DS_Store" >> .gitignore


Project Structure
my_project/
├── README.md           # Project description
├── data/              
│   ├── raw/           # Original data
│   └── processed/     # Cleaned data
├── notebooks/         # Exploration
├── src/              # Source code
├── visuals/          # Output images
├── docs/             # Documentation
└── requirements.txt   # Dependencies


Documentation Template
Your README should include: 1. Project title and description 2. Data source and collection method 3. Key findings/insights 4. Technical requirements 5. How to run the code 6. Future improvements

title: Project Tips & Resources
text:
Common Pitfalls to Avoid

Design Mistakes

🚫 Too many colors
🚫 3D charts for 2D data

🚫 Truncated y-axes
🚫 Overcrowded layouts
🚫 Decoration over function



Technical Mistakes

🚫 Not handling missing data
🚫 Hardcoded values
🚫 No error handling
🚫 Poor performance with large data
🚫 Not testing edge cases



Process Mistakes

🚫 Starting coding too early
🚫 Not iterating on designs
🚫 Ignoring user feedback
🚫 Last-minute deployment
🚫 Poor time management

title: Project Instructions
text:
Midterm Project (30%)

Objectives
Create a comprehensive static visualization report that demonstrates your understanding of design principles and technical skills.


Requirements

Use a dataset of your choice (minimum 1000 observations)
Create at least 5 different visualization types
Apply appropriate color schemes and typography
Include written analysis and design justifications
Submit as a PDF report (8-10 pages)



Deliverables

Project proposal (Week 3)
Data exploration notebook
Final visualization report
Code repository

title: Project Instructions
text:
Final Project (40%)

Objectives
Work in teams to create an interactive dashboard or data story that provides insights into a complex dataset.


Requirements

Teams of 2-3 students
Interactive elements (filters, hover, zoom)
Multiple coordinated views
Responsive design
Clear narrative structure



Deliverables

Project proposal (Week 7)
Design mockups
Interactive visualization (deployed)
Technical documentation
Team presentation (Week 10)

title: Project Instructions
text:
Project Guidelines

Choosing a Dataset

Publicly available data
Sufficient complexity for analysis
Ethical considerations addressed
Novel insights possible



Evaluation Criteria

Design (30%): Aesthetics, clarity, appropriateness
Technical (30%): Code quality, functionality, performance
Analysis (25%): Insights, storytelling, accuracy
Documentation (15%): Clarity, completeness, reproducibility
